thread.title: Women running for Vermont's top two state positions
thread.title_full: Women running for Vermont's top two state positions

title: Women running for Vermont's top two state positions
text:
Women running for Vermont's top two state offices How the state's political climate has changed for women Published 7:48 PM EDT Oct 13, 2015 
Come Election Day 2016 it's possible that women could hold Vermont’s top two state offices. Related 
Watch this story 
Those are still big “ifs” at this point, but no matter how it turns out, it is a sign that the political landscape has changed for women.“I really felt the time was right for me to step out and take on a new leadership role,” candidate for leiutenant governor Kesha Ram said. 
State Representative Ram announced Monday she is running for lieutenant governor of Vermont. 
Eight years ago, at just 22 years old, Ram was elected to the State House, but not without some backlash. 
“I remember at the time one of my opponents said, ‘I'd be curious to see what she thinks she brings to the table,’” Ram said. 
Ram was inspired to take on the new leadership role by women like Madeleine Kunin, the only woman to hold the state's top office. 
She served as governor for six years from 1985 to 1991. 
She said there were hurdles when she ran but believes a lot has changed since then. 
“I must confess, I thought after I won the barricades had been lowered and we were going to have a parade of women running for governor and we haven't. It's still rare to have a woman governor,” Ram said. 
Now Sue Minter is taking on that challenge, last week announcing her bid for governor. 
"I think Vermonters are ready for new leadership and a different voice,” Minter said when kicking off her campaign in Waterbury. 
Kunin said she's delighted to see two ladies running for the state's highest offices. 
“We think nothing of two men running for governor and lieutenant governor, so it shouldn't be a big deal to see two women running for governor and lieutenant governor,” Kunin said. “I think it's a healthy American phenomenon.” 
Ram agrees. 
”When women run they win, and when they win they lead with the best interest of Vermonters at heart,” Ram said. 
The primary election is in August 2016, followed by the general election in November.
